conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light; size and position depend on light source position.
Light source is currently positioned above the objects, casting shadows on the ground.
Moving the light source backward increases the distance between the light source and the objects.
Increased distance affects both the position and size of the shadows.
Shadows will shift closer to the objects as the light source moves backward.
Shadows will become smaller due to increased distance reducing angle of light divergence.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to their respective objects.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will become smaller.
